awd_titl_txt: Travel Support for Academically Talented Science and Engineering Undergraduates to Attend the 2024 Great Minds in STEM Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by increasing the number and diversity of students who pursue graduate education and jobs in STEM. This Travel Grant will support 35 academically talented undergraduate students to attend the 2024 Great Minds in STEM (GMiS) Conference, which will be held November 6-9, 2024, in Fort Worth, TX. The students will be recruited through a partnership with science and engineering honor societies at Minority Serving Institutions. At the conference, the students will participate in seminars, mentoring, networking, and other professional development activities focusing on readiness for STEM graduate school and STEM careers.

Educating and retaining a diverse STEM workforce enables the nation's continued innovation in STEM as well as positive societal impacts. This project will enable a diverse group of academically talented STEM undergraduates to gain knowledge and skills that prepare them for STEM graduate education and the STEM workforce. Recruitment will target students at Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs), including Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs), and Tribal Colleges and Universities (TCUs). The students who participate in the conference will learn about different sectors of STEM industries, engage in mentoring and networking activities, strengthen their identity as STEM professionals, and develop a stronger sense of belonging to the STEM community.

The NSF IUSE: EDU Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Great Minds in STEM (GMiS) was awarded grant DUE-2438572 to support STEM honor society undergraduate student travel to the 2024 GMiS Conference, held in Fort Worth, TX from November 6 - 9, 2 024. While many underrepresented engineering and science students belong to one of the seven national diversity-affinity STEM organizations, only some students are part of nationally recognized disciplinary honor societies and have built strong disciplinary affiliations that can serve them well in their future professional endeavors. It is these academically high-achieving students that GMiS sought to attract and engage in a cross-disciplinary setting and expose them to graduate school and STEM career-readiness opportunities

This project sought to encourage the most talented underserved and underrepresented students at Minority Serving Institutions (i.e., HSIs, HBCUs, TCUs, and other MSIs) to persist to graduate school as well as to prepare them for a variety of career paths post-graduation. Additionally, and significantly, it sought to build virtual peer support networks. 

Students were invited from the following honor societies:

  • Sigma Pi Sigma – The physics honor society
  • Tau Beta Pi – The engineering honor society
  • Upsilon Pi Epsilon – The computing and information disciplines honor society
  • Gamma Sigman Epsilon – chemistry honor society
  • Alpha Pi Mu – industrial engineering honor society
  • Etta Kappa Nu - electrical engineering honor society
  • Sigma Gamma Epsilon – earth science honor society
  • Chi Epsilon – civil engineering honor society
  • Beta Beta Beta – biological sciences honor society
  • Chi Omega Lamda – biological sciences honor society managed by ASBMB
  • Omega Chi Epsilon – chemical engineering honor society (web form notice completed)
  • Pi Tau Sigma – mechanical engineering honor society

Sudents also had to possess a GPA above 3.2 or on the dean's list and attend an MSI.

Thirty grantees participated in a special track where they received instruction on the benefits of graduate education, preparation for success in graduate school, and competitive positioning for employment after attending graduate school.  Students valued the experience.  Two typical comments were:

"I am writing to express my sincere gratitude for the NSF travel grant I received to attend the recently concluded Great Minds in STEM conference. I greatly appreciate the support and the opportunity to participate in the graduate school and career-planning sessions and the [graduate and career] fair. Thank you for your generosity and commitment to supporting students' professional development. I am glad I benefitted from this learning experience.”

“I absolutely loved the experience!! Thank you so much for the opportunity! I’m truly grateful!”

Intellectual Merit

• GMiS will gain insight into the STEM career-readiness of disciplinary honor society students.

• Attendees will gain (a) professional skills, knowledge and insights into recent technical advancements, (b) experience learning in an interdisciplinary environment, and (c) information on how to successfully navigate the graduate school process.

• Attendees will have opportunities for participating in STEM career-readiness seminars, developing collaborations through competition teamwork, and increasing their network among peers from other institutions and disciplines.

Broader Impacts

• Attendees will gain knowledge about graduate school and STEM career-readiness that they can share with members of their disciplinary honor societies and other STEM organizations at their home institutions or through their social media channels, thereby fostering a culture of continuous learning and improvement.

• Traditionally underserved and underrepresented students will have the opportunity to engage in academic and career development opportunities that they might not otherwise experience at their home institution or disciplinary honor society.


Last Modified: 02/13/2025
Modified by: Gary A Cruz
